newsitem.title: USA: McDonald's to open in 100th and 101st countries.
newsitem.headline: McDonald's to open in 100th and 101st countries.

text.p: McDonald's Corp., which opened its first fast-food restaurants outside the United States in 1967 in Canada and Puerto Rico, said Monday it was expanding into its 100th and 101st countries.
The world's largest restaurant chain said it planned to open outlets in Minsk, Belarus, and in Papeete, Tahiti, on Tuesday.
McDonald's also opened what it said was the world's first ski-through restaurant in the popular Swedish ski resort of Lindvallen about 280 miles northwest of Stockholm.

"With the openings of countries No. 100 and No. 101, McDonald's is present in nations accounting for about 75 percent of the world's population," Jim Cantalupo, president of McDonald's International, said in a statement.
McDonald's said it operates more than 20,000 restaurants on six continents.
"Nearly half of McDonald's systemwide sales and more than half of the company's operating income come from outside the U.S.," Cantalupo said.
McDonald's will open three restaurants in Minsk, where it has invested more than $15 million. One outlet is planned for Tahiti.
In Eastern Europe, McDonald's operates 200 restaurants in 14 countries. "We're committed to continuing that growth in Eastern Europe," Cantalupo added.
At the ski-through restaurant in Sweden, called "McSki," skiers order hamburgers and French fries through a special window and ski off, munching as they go.
The restaurant, which also has indoor seating for about 140 people, is some 110 yards from the resort's main ski lift, which can carry about 3,000 people an hour.

"The idea for the ski-through was actually under the theme of being where our customers are. Our guests decide where we should be," said Swedish McDonald's spokesman Bjorn Kallstrom at the opening ceremony for McSki.
Kallstrom said McDonald's aims to have 200 restaurants in Sweden by the year 2000, up from 120 today.

"If we find the sites we see that we can easily have that number of restaurants," Kallstrom said. "We don't have any plans for more ski-throughs in Sweden, but who knows what will happen in the future."
Kallstrom said McSki has aroused interest from McDonald's operations in other countries as well.
